nodes.text: Political institutions and incumbency rules determine dynamic selection and persistence of governments; institutional 'flexibility' affects whether high competence governments emerge and persist

Construct a dynamic discrete-time coalition game where governments are feasible coalitions, each government has a competence value, individuals get private rents from office, and changes require societal votes plus consent from some incumbents; degree of incumbency advantage is parameter l
In nonstochastic environments perfect democracy (l = 0) always leads to the emergence of the most competent government as unique stable equilibrium

Any deviation from perfect democracy (l >= 1) can generate additional stable governments; even the least competent government may be stable and persist indefinitely depending on l and initial government

There is no simple ranking among imperfect democracies or dictatorships in nonstochastic environments: some less democratic regimes may produce higher expected competence depending on initial government and institutional parameters

When the environment is stochastic (occasional shocks to government competences), higher degrees of democracy increase institutional flexibility and the long-run probability that the best government will come to power

Define (Markov) political equilibrium as a mapping from current government to next government in which transitions occur only if supported by a winning coalition and no preferable alternative exists; provide recursive characterization of equilibria via mapping phi
Prove existence and uniqueness (for acyclic equilibria) of the recursive mapping phi for high discount factors; provide sufficient conditions to rule out cyclic equilibria
Proposition: under uniform-size governments and fixed m and l, phi yields unique political equilibrium and the best government is the sole stable government when l = 0

Proposition and examples: for l >= 1 there exist multiple stable governments; constructive examples show small incumbency advantage (e.g., l =1) can make worst government stable because incumbents block sequences of improvements that would ultimately exclude them
Characterize stable governments: any two distinct stable governments share at most l-1 members; extreme dictatorship l = k makes every feasible government stable

Examples for k >=3 show nonmonotonic effects of l: intermediate or lower democracy can allow incremental or large improvements depending on number of veto players; thus institutional effects depend on distribution of abilities and initial government

Stochastic extension: with infrequent shocks, political transitions follow equilibrium mapping phi computed for each shock realization; more democracy reduces number of nearby stable governments and increases chance that a shock leads to a large jump to high competence government

Comparative results under shocks: perfect democracy immediately installs the new best government; l=1 prevents further deterioration after shock and gives positive chance to reach best government; extreme dictatorship l=k prevents any change after shocks; probability of best government is decreasing in l

Limited shocks (swapping abilities of 2 agents) and sufficient democracy imply competence is nondecreasing over time and almost sure convergence to the best government as t->infinity; similar result for swaps of x agents if l <= k - floor(x/2)

Compare junta-like (some current members must consent) vs royalty-like (certain individuals always required): royalty can outperform junta in stochastic environments when ability distribution is sufficiently convex because secure royals enable safe introduction of high-ability members
